column4: title=The Sudbury Fight, April 21, 1676: an Address delivered before the Society of Colonial Wars at the Battle Ground, Sudbury, Massachusetts, June 17, 1897

column1: The '''Attack on Sudbury,''' also known as '''The Sudbury Fight''' (April 21, 1676), was a battle of [[King Philip's War]], fought in what is today [[Sudbury, Massachusetts
column2: Sudbury]] and [[Wayland, Massachusetts]], when approximately five hundred [[Wampanoag]], [[Nipmuc]], and [[Narragansett people
column3: Narragansett]] [[Native Americans in the United States
column4: Native Americans]] raided the frontier settlement of Sudbury in [[Massachusetts Bay Colony]]. Disparate companies of [[English people
column6: militiamen]] from nearby settlements marched to the town's defense, two of which were drawn into Native ambushes and suffered heavy losses. The battle was the last major Native American victory in King Philip's War before their final defeat in southern [[New England]] in August 1676.

column1: The winter of 1676 brought a lull in the fighting of King Philip's War in eastern [[Massachusetts]], but come spring Native American forces resumed their raids on the area's [[Puritans
column2: Puritan]] towns. The Native coalition attacked the strategically significant fort at [[Marlborough, Massachusetts]] on both March 16 and April 7, destroying most of the settlement and forcing a partial evacuation of its residents. In response to these attacks, as well as the recent abandonment of [[Lancaster, Massachusetts
column4: Groton]], the colonial Council of War dispatched Captain Samuel Wadsworth and fifty men to Marlborough to reinforce the frontier. Wadsworth's company passed through Sudbury on the evening of April 20.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite book
column7: title=King Philip's War: The History and Legacy of America's Forgotten Conflict

column1: Meanwhile, a large group of Native warriors departed the Nipmuc stronghold of [[Mount Wachusett]] and gathered on Pompositticut Hill (also known as Summer Hill in what is now [[Maynard, Massachusetts]]). After a [[pow wow]],<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Narrative of the Captivity and Restoration of Mrs. Mary Rowlandson
column11: access-date=}}</ref> the group decided to attack Sudbury instead of [[Concord, Massachusetts
column12: Concord]].<ref name=\"Gutteridge\">Gutteridge, William H. (1921). ''A Brief History of the Town of Maynard, Massachusetts''. Maynard, MA: Town of Maynard, p. 13-16 [https://books.google.com/books?id=zCwWAAAAYAAJ]</ref> Tradition holds that [[Metacomet]] led the Native army at the Sudbury Fight,<ref>{{Cite web
column14: title=The Sudbury Fight, April 21, 1676: an Address delivered before the Society of Colonial Wars at the Battle Ground, Sudbury, Massachusetts, June 17, 1897
column22: access-date=}}</ref> though no primary sources corroborate it. Local historians have suggested<ref name=\":4\" /><ref>{{Cite web
column24: title=King Philip's War and the Sudbury Fight
column32: access-date=}}</ref> that Nipmuc [[sachem]] [[Muttawmp]] held overall command.

column1: Native forces infiltrated Sudbury during the night<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite book
column4: title=Flintlock and Tomahawk: New England in King Philip's War
column9: pages=173}}</ref> and attacked at dawn, burning houses and barns, as well as killing \"several persons,\" according to Puritan historian [[William Hubbard (clergyman)
column18: pages=149}}</ref> Many English residents of Sudbury (most of whom lived on the east bank of the [[Sudbury River]], in present-day Wayland) abandoned their homes and sought refuge in the town's fortified [[Garrison house
column19: garrison houses]]. The Natives besieged the Haynes garrison house on Water Row Road all morning but faced a stout defense from the English civilians within. At one point the Natives rolled a flaming cart full of [[flax]] downhill toward the garrison, only for the contraption to hit a rock and spill over before doing any damage.<ref>{{Cite book
column22: title=They Shall Not Tamely Give It Up
column27: pages=65}}</ref> The Haynes garrison held throughout the battle, though authors George Ellis and John Morris have speculated that the siege was a [[feint]] meant to draw English reinforcements to the area.<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: \"Hearing the alarm,\"<ref name=\":3\" /> about a dozen men of Concord marched to Sudbury's defense. They were ambushed and massacred within full view of the defenders of the Haynes garrison. Only one of the Concord men escaped with his life,<ref name=\":0\" /> and the dead were buried in a mass grave just east of [[Old Town Bridge (Wayland, Massachusetts)
Flushed with victory, Native forces crossed the river and set about pillaging the central settlement of Sudbury. Shortly before noon, English militiamen from [[Watertown, Massachusetts
column2: Watertown]] under the command of Captain Hugh Mason arrived and successfully repelled the raiding party.<ref name=\":0\" />

column5: A depiction of the attack on the town]]

column1: As Mason took back control of the town, Captain Wadsworth approached from the west with about seventy men, his numbers bolstered by Captain Samuel Brocklebank's garrison at Marlborough. Wadsworth's men had rested only briefly in Marlborough before their march back east to defend Sudbury; they were hungry, exhausted, and completely ignorant of their enemy's position.<ref name=\":4\">{{Cite web
column3: title=The Sudbury Fight, 1676: A Decisive Native American Victory in King Philip's War
column11: access-date=}}</ref> A mile from town, Wadsworth's men spotted about a hundred armed Natives darting off into the woods. Believing that \"these they might easily deal with,\"<ref name=\":3\" /> the militia set off in pursuit.

column1: The Natives led the militia to the low ground between Goodman's Hill and Green Hill in present-day Sudbury, where they sprang an ambush, surrounding the small English force. Wadsworth fought his way to the summit of Green Hill, ordering his men to form a square, and repulsed multiple Native charges.<ref name=\":3\" /> The fighting went on all afternoon. The Watertown militia attempted to rescue Wadsworth, as did two companies of English cavalry, to no avail.<ref name=\":4\" />

Native warriors then set fire to the dry brush of the hill, choking the English with smoke.<ref name=\":0\" /> In a panic, the English broke and ran. Half the militiamen were killed in the [[rout]], including Wadsworth and Brocklebank. The survivors fled for the Goodenow garrison house along the [[Boston Post Road]] to the south. According to [[Increase Mather]], the Natives took \"five or six of the English alive\" and \"stripped them naked, and caused them to run the gauntlet, whipping them after a cruel and bloody manner, and then threw hot ashes upon them; cut the flesh of their legs, and put fire into their wounds, delighting to see the miserable torments of wretched creatures. Thus [the Indians] are the perfect children of the Devil.\"<ref name=\":5\">{{Cite book
column4: title=A Brief History of the War With the Indians in New England
column9: pages=45}}</ref> Hubbard also claims English captives were tortured,<ref name=\":3\" /> but [[Mary Rowlandson]], a captive of the sachem [[Weetamoo]] who was present in the Native camp during the battle, makes no mention of it in her memoirs.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: As night fell, Native forces withdrew from Sudbury. Early the next day, English soldiers, together with a group of allied [[Praying Indian
column2: Praying Indians]], set out to the battlefield to bury the dead.<ref name=\":2\" />

column1:
Rowlandson claims that despite their victory, morale among the Native coalition was low after the Sudbury Fight:
\"They came home without that rejoicing and triumphing over their victory which they were wont to show at other times; but rather like dogs (as they say) which have lost their ears. Yet I could not perceive that it was for their own loss of men. They said they had not lost above five or six; and I missed none, except in one wigwam. When they went, they acted as if the Devil had told them that they should gain the victory; and now they acted as if the Devil had told them they should have a fall. Whither it were so or no, I cannot tell, but so it proved, for quickly they began to fall, and so held on that summer, till they came to utter ruin.\"
Hubbard and Mather disagree with Rowlandson, putting the Native dead at a \"hundred and twenty,\" and in the autumn of 1676, prominent citizens of Sudbury recounted that they had made a \"considerable slaughter\"{{Cite web
column3: title=Letter From the Citizens of Sudbury to the General Court of Boston, October 1676
column11: access-date=}}</ref> of Native attackers. On the morning of April 22, Native warriors taunted militiamen in Marlborough by shouting seventy-four times to indicate the number of their enemy they believed they had killed at Sudbury.<ref name=\":0\" />

column3: Harvard College]]) dedicated a memorial stone over the mass grave where his father had been buried alongside his men.<ref name=\":0\" /> The stone incorrectly dates the battle to April 18, likely an error of Hubbard's<ref name=\":3\" /> that was subsequently reprinted (both Mather<ref name=\":5\" /> and the citizens of [[17th century]] Sudbury themselves<ref name=\":6\" /> state that the battle took place on April 21). In 1852, the remains of Wadsworth's militia were excavated and reinterred fifty feet north<ref name=\":0\" /> to the site of a new monument near the base of Green Hill.

column1: A handful of other monuments and markers in Sudbury and Wayland commemorate the Sudbury Fight, most of which were erected in the 1930s to celebrate Massachusetts's [[tricentennial]]. The battlefield around Goodman's Hill and Green Hill is now the site of an affluent residential neighborhood.<ref name=\":4\" />

column2: single4     = Watch Who U Beef Wit

column1: '''''2000 B.C. (Before Can-I-Bus)''''' is the second studio album by [[rapper]] [[Canibus]], released on July 18, 2000 through [[Universal Records (defunct record label)

Considered to have been a significant improvement over his debut album, ''[[Can-I-Bus]]'', ''2000 B.C.'' featured multiple [[record producer]]s and greater differentiation. On the title track, Canibus blames the commercial failure of his first album on the bland beats by [[Wyclef Jean]] whom he severed ties with to team up with various producers, ranging from [[Ty Fyffe]] to [[Irv Gotti]]. Allegedly, rapper [[Eminem]] was to be featured on the track \"Phuk U\", but turned down the offer.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Canibus - Eminem's Enemies, Rivals and Beefs

column1: Universal Records was reportedly underwhelmed by sales of the second release (the album was bootlegged heavily before the release), {{citation needed
column2: date=October 2012}} and the label's contract with Canibus was terminated following the release of ''2000 B.C.'' The album's only charting single was \"Mic-Nificent\", which peaked at number 23 on the [[Hot Rap Singles]] chart.

column1: ''2000 B.C.'' received mixed reviews from [[Music journalism
column2: music critic]]s, calling it an improvement over his [[Can-I-Bus
column3: debut album]] but still found problems with Canibus' lack of engaging topics, monotonous flow and subpar production. At [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[Standard score
column4: normalized]] score out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the album received an [[Weighted mean
column5: average]] score of 60, based on 9 reviews.<ref name=\"Metacritic\"/>

column1: Steve 'Flash' Juon of ''RapReviews'' praised the album's production for its bass-heavy underground approach and Canibus' lyrics for containing more vile and vitriol than his debut's pop rap content, saying that, \"As a whole this sophomore album is easily as good or better than the first, but whether this will satisfy the people who've already written off Canibus is still anyone's guess.\"<ref name=\"RR\"/> [[Nathan Rabin]] of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'', despite finding the production uneven, the featured guests lacking lyrically and the use of a song structure missing, praised Canibus for lacing the songs by amplifying his battle-rapping style with imaginative content, saying that he \"invests his rhymes with such dark humor, vivid imagery, and controlled passion that his lack of thematic ambition is forgivable.\"<ref>{{cite news
column10: accessdate=July 30, 2015}}</ref> Wall of Sound's Jackie McCarthy praised the production for being subtle and using samples sparingly and Canibus' lyrical content, concluding that, \"If ''2000 B.C.'' is Canibus' attempt to rewrite his own musical history, erasing his missteps with [[LL Cool J]] and Wyclef, it'll be interesting to see who his next target will be.\"<ref name=\"WofS\"/>

column1: Matt Conaway of [[AllMusic]] was mixed about the album, praising Canibus' delivery and battle rhymes for being attention-grabbing to the ears, but felt indifferent to the drum tracks conducted by the new producers, concluding that his \"vast potential remains largely unrealized thanks to bland production.\"<ref name=\"AM\"/> ''[[NME]]'' also commented on the production, saying that outside \"The C-Quel\" and the title track, it feels monotonous afterwards, saying that, \"There's just not enough concepts or ideas on show - every song is a fist-fight to the death.\"<ref name=\"NME\"/> Tony Green of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' praised the album's first half for being able to match the production with Canibus' angry-filled lyrics but felt that the aggression depletes later on, concluding that, \"Still, ''2000'' is a cut above his debut, making it the kind of second chance that you don't often get in the music biz.\"<ref name=\"RS\"/>

Christopher O'Connor of SonicNet felt that the album was wasted potential and only exhibited inner male rage, concluding that, \"It's ironic that for all of his intelligence, passion and obvious talent, Canibus chose to stoop to the caveman mentality so apparent on this release. 2000 B.C., indeed.\"<ref name=\"SonicNet\"/> [[Craig Seymour]], writing for ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', criticized Canibus for crafting the album with anger-filled tracks and should utilize his talents to make better songs.<ref name=\"EW\"/> [[Jon Caramanica]] from ''[[Vibe (magazine)
column2: Vibe]]'' said that despite the album having the appropriate production, Canibus still spits disses like he's going to war and will continue doing so with bloody hands, concluding that, \"It's a hollow victory if there ever was one.\"<ref>{{cite journal

column1: <!--this section is for album credits only-->

column2: 4, 3, 2, 1]]\" by [[LL Cool J]], \"Beasts From the East\" by [[Lost Boyz]], \"Desperados\" by [[The Firm (hip hop group)
column3: The Firm]], \"How We Roll\" by Canibus, \"Making a Name for Ourselves\" by [[Common (rapper)
column4: Common]] and \"[[Theme from S.W.A.T.]]\" by [[Rhythm Heritage]]<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Tracks Sampled in The C-Quel by Canibus

column2: Requiem Mass in D Minor]]\" by [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]] and \"[[I Know You Got Soul (Eric B. & Rakim song)
column3: I Know You Got Soul]]\" by [[Eric B. & Rakim]]<ref>{{cite web

minor tweaks,safe,Chidgk1,"'''Climate communication''' or '''climate change communication''' is a field of [[environmental communication]]s and [[science communication]] focused on facilitating the communications of the effects of [[Global warming
column2: anthropogenic climate change]]. Most climate communication focuses on bringing knowledge from the scientific consensus on the impact of climate change to a broader public.

column1: The field of climate communication explores two main areas: the efficacy of existing communications strategies, and supporting the development of recommendations for improving that communication. Improving climate change communication has become the focus of several major research institutes, such as the [[Yale Program on Climate Change Communication]] and Climate Outreach in the UK, as well as major international organizations, such as the IPCC and [[UN Climate Change Secretariat]], and [[Non-governmental organization

In her Encyclopedia article in Oxford's Communications Research Encyclopedia, scholar Amy E. Chadwick describes Climate Change Communication as a new field emerging in the 1990s.<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web
column13: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> Early studies were connected to other environmental communications concerns such as exploring awareness and understanding of [[ozone depletion]].<ref name=\":2\" /> {{As of
column15: }}, most research in this field has been conducted in the United States, United Kingdom, Australia, Canada, and Western European countries.<ref name=\":2\" />

column1: Because of the importance of the larger scale [[Climate change mitigation
column2: public action required in addressing climate change]], a significant part of climate communications is focused on understanding barriers to public understanding and action on climate change. In particular, the evidence shows that the [[information deficit model]] of communication—where climate change communicators assume  \"if the public only knew more about the evidence they would act\"—doesn't work. Instead, [[argumentation theory]] indicates that different audiences need different kinds of persuasive argumentation and communication.
climate denialism]] by organizations such as the [[The Heartland Institute]] in the United States, introduces [[misinformation]] into public discourse and understanding.

column1: There are several models for explaining why the public doesn't act once more informed. One of the theoretical models for this is the 5 Ds model created by [[Per Espen Stoknes
column4: title=The 5 psychological barriers to climate action
column10: access-date=2020-04-12}}</ref> Stokes describes 5 major barriers to creating action from climate communication:

column1: # '''Distance''' - many effects and impacts of climate change feel distant from individual lives
# '''Doom -''' when framed as a disaster, the message backfires, causing [[Eco-anxiety]]
# '''Dissonance''' - a disconnect between the problems (mainly the fossil fuel economy) and the things that people choose in their lives
# '''Denial''' -- psychological self defense to avoid becoming overwhelmed by fear or guilt
# '''iDentity''' -- disconnects created by social identities, such as [[Conservatism
column2: conservative]] values, which are threatened by the changes that need to happen because of climate change.

column1: As of 2008, most of the environmental communications evidence for effecting individual or social change were focused on behavior changes around: [[Domestic energy consumption
column3: recycling behaviours]], changing transportation behavior and buying green products.<ref name=\":1\" /> At that time, there were few examples of [[multi-level communications]] strategies for effecting change.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: A significant part of the research and public advocacy conversations about climate change have focused on the effectiveness of different terms used to describe \"global warming\".

column2: Climate change and health}}Climate change exacerbates a number of existing public health issues, such as [[mosquito-borne disease]], and introduce new public health concerns related to changing climate, such as increase in health concerns after natural disasters or increases in [[heat illness]]es. Thus the field of [[health communication]] has long acknowledged the importance of treating climate change as a public health issue, requiring broad population behavior changes that allow societal [[climate change adaptation]].<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite journal
column10: title=Communication and Marketing As Climate Change–Intervention Assets
column17: doi=10.1016/j.amepre.2008.08.016}}</ref> A December 2008 article in the [[American Journal of Preventive Medicine]] recommended using two broad sets of tools to effect this change: communication and [[social marketing]].<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: The effect of mass media and journalism on the public's attitudes towards climate change has been a significant part of communications studies. In particular, scholars have looked at how media's tendency to cover climate change changes regionally, with different audiences (i.e. [[Fox News]]'s dismissive coverage of climate change news) and the tendency of newsrooms to cover climate change as a issue of uncertainty or debate, in order to give a sense of balance.<ref name=\":2\" />

Further research has explored how popular media, like the film ''[[The Day After Tomorrow]]'' and popular documentary [[An Inconvenient Truth]] change public perceptions of climate change.<ref name=\":2\" />

Effective climate communications require audience and contextual awareness. Different organizations have published guides and frameworks based on experience in climate communications. This section documents those various guidelines.

column2: IPCC]] published a handbook of guidance for IPCC authors about effective climate communication. It is based on extensive social studies research exploring the impact of different tactics for climate communication.<ref>{{Cite web
column13: access-date=2020-04-12}}</ref> The guidelines focus on six main principles:

column1: # Talk about the real world, not abstract idea
# Connect with what matters to your audience
# Use the most effective visual communication
Climate Visuals a nonprofit, publishes a set of guidelines based on evidence for climate communications.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2020-04-12}}</ref> They recommend that visual communication include:

column1: # Show climate change causes at scale

The impacts of climate change are exacerbated in low- and middle income countries; higher levels of poverty, less access to technologies, and less education, means that this audience needs different information. The [[Paris Agreement]] and [[IPCC]] both acknowledge the importance of [[sustainable development]] in addressing these differences. Non profit, [[Climate and Development Knowledge Network]] published a set of lessons learned and guidelines based on their experience communicating climate change in Latin America, Asia and Africa.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=GUIDE: Communicating climate change - A practitioner's guide

column1: Major research centers in climate communication include:
* [[Center for Climate Change Communication]] at [[George Mason University]]

[[Category:Climate communication]]","'''Climate communication''' or '''climate change communication''' is a field of [[environmental communication]]s and [[Science communication]] focused on facilitating the communications of the effects of [[Global warming
column2: anthropogenic climate change]]. Most climate communication focuses on bringing knowledge from the scientific consensus on the impact of climate change to a broader public.

column1: The field of climate communication explores two main areas: the efficacy of existing communications strategies, and supporting the development of recommendations for improving that communication. Improving climate change communication has become the focus of several major research institutes, such as the [[Yale Program on Climate Change Communication]] and Climate Outreach in the UK, as well as major international organizations, such as the IPCC and [[UN Climate Change Secretariat]], and NGOS.

In her Encyclopedia article in Oxford's Communications Research Encyclopedia, scholar Amy E. Chadwick describes Climate Change Communication as a new field emerging in the 1990s.<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web
column13: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> Early studies were connected to other [[environmental communication]]<nowiki/>s concerns such as exploring awareness and understanding of the [[ozone depletion]].<ref name=\":2\" /> As of 2017, most research in this field has been conducted in the United States, United Kingdom, Australia, Canada, and Western European countries.<ref name=\":2\" />

column1: The importance of the larger scale [[Climate change mitigation
column2: public action required in addressing climate change]], a significant part of climate communications is focused on understanding barriers to public understanding and action on climate change. Instead, [[argumentation theory]] indicates that different audiences need different kinds of persuasive argumentation and communication.

column1: '''Breeze Airways''' (initially Moxy Airways) is a planned [[airline]] in the [[United States]] due to begin operations in 2020. The airline was founded by [[David Neeleman]] (who previously co-founded [[Morris Air]], [[WestJet]], [[JetBlue]], and [[Azul Linhas Aereas]]).<!--<ref name=AirlineWeekly17jun2018/>-->
In June 2018, Neeleman planned a new United States airline, to be named Moxy, with [[Share capital
column2: capital]] from former [[Air Canada]] CEO [[Robert Milton]], former [[ILFC]] CEO Henri Courpron, former JetBlue Chairman of the Board Michael Lazarus and himself.<!--<ref name=AirlineWeekly17jun2018>--> They perceived that due to consolidation, all 11 [[major carrier]]s were profitable and had existed 20 years ago (except [[JetBlue]], which Neeleman had started in 2000) and that there was space for a new [[Competition (economics)

column1: In February 2020, Neeleman expressed the view that the airline would be known as the \"World’s Nicest Airline\".<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=A new, potentially industry-altering airline from the man who brought you JetBlue

column1: Breeze professes that it wants to offer a low cost product - but says it also plans to offer a first class product; so it will not be operating a true [[low cost carrier]] (LCC) model.

The proposals do include some LCC features (such as a point-to-point route network, extra fees for additional services, and (originally) a single class of aircraft), but it will not have a single class of cabin (those paying higher fares are promised a 2-2 seat configuration and more legroom)<ref name=\"CondeNastDN\" /> and indeed Breeze says it will charge for \"what’s effectively four classes of service, starting with an ultra-low-fare product, from which you can buy your way up the ladder... \".  Aircraft will not feature seatback [[in-flight entertainment]]; instead entertainment will be streamed through the airline's app, which will also be used to purchase flights and upgrades.<ref name=\"CondeNastDN\" />
Breeze plans to offer point-to-point service between secondary airports, potentially including;<ref>{{Cite web

column1: →‎External links:add authority control,safe,Ser Amantio di Nicolao,"[[File:Calistrat Hogas.jpg

'''Calistrat Hogaș''' (born '''Calistrat Dumitriu'''; April 19, 1848 – August 28, 1917) was a Moldavian, later Romanian prose writer. The son of a [[Tecuci]] priest, he studied at [[Iași University]] before beginning an over four-decade career as a high school teacher, often at [[Piatra Neamț]]. Meanwhile, he made several false starts as a writer before finding a suitable genre, namely stories drawn from his mountain rambles that appeared starting in 1907. He did not manage to collect his works during his lifetime, but these appeared to great success in 1921.

Born in [[Tecuci]], his parents were Gheorghe Dumitriu, a [[Romanian Orthodox]] [[archpriest]], and his wife Mărioara (''née'' Stanciu),<ref name=\"sasu\"/> the daughter of a ''[[Serdar (Ottoman rank)
column2: serdar]]'' from [[Pechea]], [[Galați County]]. He was the first or second of eight children, and various birthdates between 1847 and 1852 have been suggested, but April 19, 1848 appears likeliest.<ref>Hogaș, p. ix</ref> His adopted surname was a nickname of his grandfather's that was assigned to him in primary school as a way to distinguish him from other pupils named Dumitriu. After completing the primary grades in his native town, he attended middle and high school at ''[[Academia Mihăileană]]'' and at the [[National College (Iași)
column3: National College]] in [[Iași]] from 1859 to 1867.<ref name=\"sasu\"/> [[Alexandru Dimitrie Xenopol]], [[Vasile Conta]], [[Alexandru Lambrior]], [[Constantin Dimitrescu-Iași]] and [[George Panu]] were all classmates, and he befriended the last three.<ref>Hogaș, p. xi</ref> From 1867 to 1869, he attended the literature faculty of [[Iași University]].<ref name=\"sasu\"/> Panu and Lambrior remained university classmates, and he was noticed as a good student during high school by [[Titu Maiorescu]], with whom he also came in touch during his university years. Nevertheless, he did not join the ''[[Junimea]]'' society of which the latter was president, and which at the time was a sure path to advancement of one's literary reputation. From 1869, he worked as a teacher of Romanian language and literature at the new gymnasium in [[Piatra Neamț]], where he was also director and handled all the humanities courses.<ref name=\"o109\">Ornea, p. 109</ref> In January 1870, he married Elena Gheorghiu, the daughter of a Piatra Neamț priest; the couple had eight children.<ref>Octavian Botez, Jana Balacciu, ''Calistrat Hogaș: amintiri și articole critice'', p. 177. Bucharest: Editura Eminescu, 1976</ref> A lover of Greek and Roman culture, he gave them names such as Cleopatra, Cornelia, Sidonia and Aețiu.<ref>Hogaș, p. xiii</ref> In 1878, he left Piatra Neamț for a period of three years, teaching first at the gymnasium in Tecuci and then at a normal school in Iași, and then lived in the former town from 1881 to 1885.<ref>Hogaș, p. xiv</ref> He subsequently taught in Tecuci, [[Alexandria, Romania
column5: Roman]];<ref name=\"sasu\"/> during this period, from the mid-1880s to the late 1890s, he published only sporadically. His reluctance to write was deepened by the accidental death of his 18-year-old daughter in 1894.<ref>Hogaș, p. xx</ref> From 1898, he was a teacher at the [[Costache Negruzzi National College
column6: Boarding High School]] in Iași.<ref name=\"sasu\"/>

column1: His literary debut consisted of verses that appeared in the Piatra Neamț newspaper ''Corespondența provincială'' in 1874. In the same town, he founded a newspaper, ''Situațiunea'', that briefly appeared in 1878.<ref name=\"sasu\"/> While living there, he began climbing the local mountains.<ref name=\"o109\"/> Between 1881 and 1882, he was a school inspector in [[Neamț County]], coming to know [[Ion Luca Caragiale]] in this capacity.<ref name=\"sasu\"/> From his return to Piatra Neamț in 1881 until 1885, Hogaș contributed to ''Asachi'' magazine; his first contributions to the ''Amintiri din o călătorie'' series appeared there from 1882 to 1884, but they had no resonance with critics.<ref name=\"sasu\"/><ref name=\"o109\"/> Invited to submit poetry to a [[Bucharest]] magazine, he refused, probably aware of their antiquated style.<ref name=\"o109\"/> He continued the ''Amintiri'' series in Xenopol's magazine ''Arhiva'' from 1893 to 1902;<ref name=\"sasu\"/> these contributions also went unnoticed, as the magazine was not taken seriously.<ref name=\"o109\"/>

The 1906 establishment of ''[[Viața Românească]]'', the formation of a group surrounding the magazine and his resulting friendship with [[Garabet Ibrăileanu]] were crucial to his career; his ''În munții Neamțului'' and other travel notes appeared there from 1907 to 1912.<ref name=\"sasu\"/> He cut an odd and colorful picture at Iași: a large man, dressed unusually, wearing a woolen jacket in all seasons, with a huge overcoat and an equally sizable hat, wearing thick boots in winter and custom made sandals in summer, he hustled between the three high schools where he taught, after a breakfast consisting of a chunk of meat roasted over coals, seasoned with a handful of onions and washed down with a pot of coffee. His ''Viața Românească'' colleagues respected Hogaș and treated him as a friend, even though he was older than all of them; they asked his advice and unanimously admired his contributions. Caragiale considered him a great writer and spoke glowingly of his writings.<ref name=\"o110\"/>

He decided to collect his writings in book form in 1912, the year he retired from teaching. Hogaș insisted on making the manuscript corrections himself, but the copies were destroyed because they contained a devastating number of typographical errors; the new edition, from 1914, was almost entirely destroyed in a fire that burned down the warehouse of ''Viața Românească''.<ref name=\"sasu\"/><ref name=\"o110\"/> He was rejected for a prize from the [[Romanian Academy]], most likely due to a report drawn up by [[Ioan D. Caragiani]].<ref name=\"sasu\"/> Nostalgic for his teaching days, Hogaș found his strength diminished and compared his retirement to [[Ovid]]'s exile in [[Constanța
column2: Tomis]].<ref name=\"h26\"/> He withdrew to Piatra Neamț in his last years and did not live to see his book appear, due to the ongoing World War I; he died at Roman.<ref name=\"sasu\"/> Initially interred there, he was later exhumed, the coffin transported on an ox-drawn cart covered in pine branches, and reburied at Piatra Neamț, in accordance with his wishes.<ref name=\"h26\">Hogaș, p. xxvi</ref> It was only in 1921 that his collected works appeared: covering two volumes, ''Amintiri dintr-o călătorie'' and ''În munții Neamțului'', the second was prefaced by [[Mihail Sadoveanu]],<ref name=\"sasu\"/> a devoted admirer. The book was a critical success,<ref name=\"o110\">Ornea, p. 110</ref> and he was posthumously granted the [[Romanian Writers' Society]] Prize in 1921. A storyteller full of charm, he referred to himself as an \"explorer\" of Moldavia's \"colossal\" mountains.<ref name=\"sasu\"/> Riding his horse Pisicuța, he would take random journeys into the mountains. Never keeping a diary, he would set down his observations in the genre that won him posthumous renown: the travel account.<ref name=\"o110\"/> His prose is strongly marked by reminiscences from his reading, which he integrated into a parodic and humorous vision.<ref name=\"sasu\">Aurel Sasu (ed.), ''Dicționarul biografic al literaturii române'', vol. I, p. 725. Pitești: Editura Paralela 45, 2004. {{ISBN

column1: While [[George Călinescu]] considered him merely \"a talented, one-dimensional dilettante\", other critics, including Ibrăileanu, [[Tudor Vianu]], [[Vladimir Streinu]] (who edited his works between 1944 and 1947), [[Șerban Cioculescu]], [[Constantin Ciopraga]] (who put out another edition in 1956), [[Al. Săndulescu]] and [[Alexandru Călinescu]] treated his writings with understanding and objectivity. They commented on his literary discourse, his romanticism, evocation of landscapes and classical allusions. In 1944, Cioculescu classified him as a practitioner of the [[Baroque]], while Alexandru Călinescu observed that his corpus is an amalgam, a mosaic of styles and mannerisms.<ref name=\"o111\">Ornea, p. 111</ref> A critical edition, with preface and commentary by Săndulescu, appeared in 1984.<ref>Ornea, pp. 111–12</ref> [[Zigu Ornea]] noted the \"observer's and moralist's talent\" with which he imagined \"tales of an ineffable quality. He was not just a poet of the forest universe but also had an excellent, memorable ability to sketch characters, an extraordinary gift for recreating dialogue.\" He went on to deny that Hogaș was another [[Ion Creangă]], as had been claimed, \"but a city dweller who knew the habits of the mountain environment and the practices of the mountain people\", endowed with \"a rare capacity for depicting nature, with all its meanings and its beauties\",<ref>Ornea, pp. 110–11</ref> \"a seductive refinement and charm and surprise and delight\".<ref name=\"o111\"/> Excerpts from Hogaș appeared in textbooks for many years, but interest in him waned after the [[Romanian Revolution]], to the point that [[Nicolae Manolescu]] called him \"a nearly forgotten writer\". In 2007, in an effort to make him relevant for a modern audience, [[Mircea A. Diaconu]] published a book-length monographic study of Hogaș.<ref>{{in lang
column2: ro}} Daniel Dragomirescu, [http://www.romlit.ro/actualitatea_unui_scriitor_uitat Actualitatea unui 'scriitor uitat'\"] {{Webarchive

column1: After his death, his widow and two of his daughters continued to reside in his house in Piatra Neamț; in 1939, his daughter Sidonia opened a private museum in one of the rooms. In 1969, the entire house was opened to the public as a state-owned museum, and since 1994 it has attempted to reconstitute the appearance it had during the writer's last five years.<ref>{{in lang
column2: ro}} [http://www.neamt.ro/cmj/memoriale/mmch.html Muzeul Memorial Calistrat Hogaș], at the Neamț County Museum Complex site</ref> Several sites connected with Hogaș are listed as [[Monument istoric
column3: historic monuments]] by Romania's [[Ministry of Culture and Religious Affairs (Romania)
column4: Ministry of Culture and Religious Affairs]]. In Tecuci, there are two: his mid-19th century house and a more modern bust.<ref>{{in lang
column5: ro}} [http://www.patrimoniu.ro/images/LMI/LMI-2010_GL.pdf Lista Monumentelor Istorice 2010: Județul Galați]</ref> Piatra Neamț has three: the 19th century house that is now a museum, a 1924 bas-relief that features him in the center, and his grave. His 19th century villa in Roman is also listed.<ref>{{in lang
column6: ro}} [http://www.patrimoniu.ro/images/LMI/LMI-2010_NT.pdf Lista Monumentelor Istorice 2010: Județul Neamț]{{Dead link
column10: Calistrat Hogaș National College]] in Piatra Neamț, where he taught, has borne his name since 1970,<ref>{{in lang
column11: ro}} [http://www.calistrathogas.ro/index.php?page=istoric Istoric] at the Calistrat Hogaș National College site</ref> while Tecuci's [[Calistrat Hogaș National College (Piatra Neamț)
column12: Calistrat Hogaș National College]] has done so since 1990.<ref>{{in lang
column13: ro}} [http://www.cnchogastecuci.ro/liceu.php Scurt istoric] at the Calistrat Hogaș National College site</ref>

column2: House and museum in Piatra Neamț

column1: Bustul lui Calistrat Hogaş din Iaşi.jpg
*Calistrat Hogaș, Daciana Vlădoiu, Al. Săndulescu (eds.), ''Opere'', vol. I. Bucharest: Editura Minerva, 1984

'''Calistrat Hogaș''' (born '''Calistrat Dumitriu'''; April 19, 1848 – August 28, 1917) was a Moldavian, later Romanian prose writer. The son of a [[Tecuci]] priest, he studied at [[Iași University]] before beginning an over four-decade career as a high school teacher, often at [[Piatra Neamț]]. Meanwhile, he made several false starts as a writer before finding a suitable genre, namely stories drawn from his mountain rambles that appeared starting in 1907. He did not manage to collect his works during his lifetime, but these appeared to great success in 1921.

Born in [[Tecuci]], his parents were Gheorghe Dumitriu, a [[Romanian Orthodox]] [[archpriest]], and his wife Mărioara (''née'' Stanciu),<ref name=\"sasu\"/> the daughter of a ''[[Serdar (Ottoman rank)
column2: serdar]]'' from [[Pechea]], [[Galați County]]. He was the first or second of eight children, and various birthdates between 1847 and 1852 have been suggested, but April 19, 1848 appears likeliest.<ref>Hogaș, p. ix</ref> His adopted surname was a nickname of his grandfather's that was assigned to him in primary school as a way to distinguish him from other pupils named Dumitriu. After completing the primary grades in his native town, he attended middle and high school at ''[[Academia Mihăileană]]'' and at the [[National College (Iași)
column3: National College]] in [[Iași]] from 1859 to 1867.<ref name=\"sasu\"/> [[Alexandru Dimitrie Xenopol]], [[Vasile Conta]], [[Alexandru Lambrior]], [[Constantin Dimitrescu-Iași]] and [[George Panu]] were all classmates, and he befriended the last three.<ref>Hogaș, p. xi</ref> From 1867 to 1869, he attended the literature faculty of [[Iași University]].<ref name=\"sasu\"/> Panu and Lambrior remained university classmates, and he was noticed as a good student during high school by [[Titu Maiorescu]], with whom he also came in touch during his university years. Nevertheless, he did not join the ''[[Junimea]]'' society of which the latter was president, and which at the time was a sure path to advancement of one's literary reputation. From 1869, he worked as a teacher of Romanian language and literature at the new gymnasium in [[Piatra Neamț]], where he was also director and handled all the humanities courses.<ref name=\"o109\">Ornea, p. 109</ref> In January 1870, he married Elena Gheorghiu, the daughter of a Piatra Neamț priest; the couple had eight children.<ref>Octavian Botez, Jana Balacciu, ''Calistrat Hogaș: amintiri și articole critice'', p. 177. Bucharest: Editura Eminescu, 1976</ref> A lover of Greek and Roman culture, he gave them names such as Cleopatra, Cornelia, Sidonia and Aețiu.<ref>Hogaș, p. xiii</ref> In 1878, he left Piatra Neamț for a period of three years, teaching first at the gymnasium in Tecuci and then at a normal school in Iași, and then lived in the former town from 1881 to 1885.<ref>Hogaș, p. xiv</ref> He subsequently taught in Tecuci, [[Alexandria, Romania
column5: Roman]];<ref name=\"sasu\"/> during this period, from the mid-1880s to the late 1890s, he published only sporadically. His reluctance to write was deepened by the accidental death of his 18-year-old daughter in 1894.<ref>Hogaș, p. xx</ref> From 1898, he was a teacher at the [[Costache Negruzzi National College
column6: Boarding High School]] in Iași.<ref name=\"sasu\"/>

His ''Viața Românească'' colleagues respected Hogaș and treated him as a friend, even though he was older than all of them; they asked his advice and unanimously admired his contributions. Caragiale considered him a great writer and spoke glowingly of his writings.<ref name=\"o110\"/>

He decided to collect his writings in book form in 1912, the year he retired from teaching. Hogaș insisted on making the manuscript corrections himself, but the copies were destroyed because they contained a devastating number of typographical errors; the new edition, from 1914, was almost entirely destroyed in a fire that burned down the warehouse of ''Viața Românească''.<ref name=\"sasu\"/><ref name=\"o110\"/> He was rejected for a prize from the [[Romanian Academy]], most likely due to a report drawn up by [[Ioan D. Caragiani]].<ref name=\"sasu\"/> Nostalgic for his teaching days, Hogaș found his strength diminished and compared his retirement to [[Ovid]]'s exile in [[Constanța
column2: Tomis]].<ref name=\"h26\"/> He withdrew to Piatra Neamț in his last years and did not live to see his book appear, due to the ongoing World War I; he died at Roman.<ref name=\"sasu\"/> Initially interred there, he was later exhumed, the coffin transported on an ox-drawn cart covered in pine branches, and reburied at Piatra Neamț, in accordance with his wishes.<ref name=\"h26\">Hogaș, p. xxvi</ref> It was only in 1921 that his collected works appeared: covering two volumes, ''Amintiri dintr-o călătorie'' and ''În munții Neamțului'', the second was prefaced by [[Mihail Sadoveanu]],<ref name=\"sasu\"/> a devoted admirer. I, p. 725. Pitești: Editura Paralela 45, 2004. {{ISBN

column4: title=Farewell To British Game Design Legend Mike Singleton

known_for = ''[[The Lords of Midnight]]''
''[[Doomdark's Revenge]]''
''[[Midwinter (video game)

employer = Cheshire Education Authority
Postern Software
PetSoft
Beyond Software
[[Krome Studios Melbourne

column1: '''Mike Singleton''' (21 February 1951 – 10 October 2012) was a British [[video game designer]] who wrote various well-regarded titles for the [[ZX Spectrum]] during the 1980s.  His titles include ''[[The Lords of Midnight]]'', ''[[Doomdark's Revenge]]'', ''[[Dark Sceptre]]'', ''[[War in Middle Earth (1988 video game)
column2: War in Middle Earth]]'' and ''[[Midwinter (video game)
column3: Midwinter]]''.  Before developing video games, Singleton was an English teacher in [[Ellesmere Port]], Cheshire, England.

column1: Singleton originally started programming in the late 1970s, and writing ''Computer Race'', a horse racing game he designed for a betting shop on the [[Commodore PET]].<ref name=crash14>{{cite magazine
column3: title=I BET TOLKIEN DID THE SAME
column7: issue=14}}</ref>  Moving on from this, he began working on [[arcade game]]s for the Pet, working with PetSoft, where he wrote ''Space Ace'' entirely in [[MOS Technology 6502
column8: 6502]] [[machine code]].  The game broke sales records of the day by selling three hundred copies.<ref name=crash41>{{cite magazine

column1: Singleton's association with PetSoft turned out to be short-lived, as PetSoft, who had been due to enter into a contract with [[Sinclair Research Ltd.
column2: Sinclair Research]] in [[Cambridge]] to write software for the new [[Sinclair ZX80
column3: ZX80]], lost out on the deal to [[Psion (computers)
column4: Psion]].  Singleton contacted British inventor and entrepreneur [[Clive Sinclair]] and was asked to send his games along.<ref name=crash41 />  He was then asked to visit the site in Cambridge, and invited to work on software for their brand new [[Sinclair ZX81

column1: Singleton used this as the platform for his ''GamesPack1'' project. ''GamesPack1'' was a series of games, each fitting into just 1 [[kilobyte]] of memory.  It was one of the first commercial software programs written for the ZX81, and something of a runaway success, selling a massive 90,000 copies, earning Singleton [[Pound sterling
column2: £]]6,000 for his efforts,<ref name=crash41 /> having taken him just two weeks over the Christmas holidays to complete.<ref name=crash14 />

column1: Whilst the arcade game writing business was making him a living, Singleton, who retired from teaching completely in 1982 to become a full-time freelance [[video game designer
column2: games designer]], was always an old school war gamer at heart,<ref name=sua85>{{cite magazine
column8: pages=39–42}}</ref> hooked from an early age on war [[board game]]s and [[Play-by-mail game
column9: play-by-mail]] (PBM) strategy gaming, working for a time on ''Seventh Empire'', a PBM game he put together for ''[[Computer and Video Games (magazine)
column10: Computer and Video Games]]'' magazine (''C&VG''),<ref name=sua85 /> which eventually led to [[Beyond Software]] when ''C&VG'' editor Terry Pratt moved to run Beyond.<ref name=crash14 />

column1: In March 1984, Singleton's spy-themed board game, ''Treachery'', which had its complicated game logic controlled by a computer program, was featured in ''C&VG'', with a type-in listing for the Spectrum, together with a keyboard overlay (a common feature of his games), centre-spread board and a set of counters.  The game was so popular among the readers that the editor asked for conversions for the [[Commodore 64]] and [[BBC Micro]] to be produced, and each of them featured in ''C&VG'''s 1985 yearbook.

It was from Beyond that Singleton, who remained freelance, was by September 1983 being pressed for more programs, and having progressed to the Sinclair ZX Spectrum, he wrote what are widely regarded as some of the best strategy adventure games ever to be seen on those early home microcomputers,<ref name=\"PlanSinc\">{{cite web
column3: title=Planet Sinclair: The Sinclair Industry: Programmers: Mike Singleton
column6: accessdate=2016-06-27}}</ref> the ''Midnight'' series: ''[[Lords of Midnight]]'' (released in July 1984) and ''[[Doomdark's Revenge]]'', which were originally intended to form the first two episodes in a trilogy of which, the final episode, ''[[Eye of the Moon]]'', never came about. Each of the two games played out on a scale never seen before back in the mid-eighties, at a time when many games were boasting 50 or even 100 locations, ''Lords of Midnight'''s groundbreaking gameplay featured over 4,000 locations, and ''Doomdark's Revenge'', 6,000, plus well in excess of 100 player controllable characters.  Had ''Eye of the Moon'' come to fruition, it was to have had around 24,000 locations, in a map featuring twelve distinct regions, each with a local sub-quest completely separate from the main objective of the game.<ref name=crash41 />

column1: Moving on from the ''Midnight'' series, Singleton worked on several games of a more arcade-like nature, the first of which, ''[[Throne of Fire]]'',<ref name=\"PlanSinc\" /> a side viewed live action game, featured a multiplayer option where each player used the same computer to explore simultaneously, each trying to complete a set of objectives which lead to the overall completion of the game. ''[[Dark Sceptre]]'',<ref name=\"PlanSinc\" /> released later the same year, was also in essence a sideways viewed live action game, but returned to a more adventure-like feel, with a long, drawn out challenge awaiting the player who would need to build up their forces to consolidate their position before seizing on the opportunity to actually complete the game.

Two years later, ''[[War in Middle-earth]]'',<ref name=\"PlanSinc\" /> whilst essentially an [[adventure game]] on a similar scale to the ''Midnight'' series, represented a switch from the adventure to an action philosophy, requiring the player to interact with the characters under their control directly, moving them individually in each of the battles,<ref name=crash41 /> giving the game much more of an arcade/adventure feel.
In the late 1980s, Singleton moved onto the [[16-bit]] machines that were making an appearance, and worked on the classic ''[[Midwinter (video game)
column2: Midwinter]]'' trilogy, also producing another work in the ''Lords of Midnight'' series in 1995, [[Lords of Midnight: The Citadel]].

column1: In the 21st century, Singleton continued working in games design, making him one of a few developers to have made the transition to more modern consoles from the early days of home computing. Singleton worked for [[Midas Interactive]] and [[LucasArts]] on several games for the [[Xbox (console)
column2: Xbox]] and [[PlayStation]] consoles, such as the action games ''[[HyperSonic Xtreme]]'' and ''[[Indiana Jones and the Emperor's Tomb]]''. Singleton worked on the strategy game ''[[Wrath Unleashed]]'', with his latest productions being ''[[Gauntlet: Seven Sorrows]]'', a continuation of the 80s arcade classic ''[[Gauntlet (arcade game)
column3: Gauntlet]]'' series of games, and ''[[Race Driver: Grid]]'', a racing game developed by [[Codemasters]].<ref>{{moby developer
column5: name=Singleton's profile}}</ref> At the time of his death after suffering from cancer,<ref>{{Citation
column6: title = RIP Mike Singleton, the RPG visionary who revolutionised the genre
column12: accessdate = 30 November 2019}}</ref> Singleton was working on an iPhone port of ''Lords of Midnight''.<ref>{{cite web

column1: * [http://www.midnightmu.com Midnight/MU – A browser-based multiplayer game based on The Lords of Midnight/Doomdarks Revenge]

column1: '''Mike Singleton''' (21 February 1951 – 10 October 2012) was a British [[video game designer]] who wrote various well-regarded titles for the [[ZX Spectrum]] during the 1980s.  His titles include ''[[The Lords of Midnight]]'', ''[[Doomdark's Revenge]]'', ''[[Dark Sceptre]]'', ''[[War in Middle Earth (1988 video game)
column2: War in Middle Earth]]'' and ''[[Midwinter (video game)
column3: Midwinter]]''.  Before developing video games, Singleton was an English teacher in [[Ellesmere Port]], Cheshire, England.

column1: Singleton originally started programming in the late 1970s, and writing ''Computer Race'', a horse racing game he designed for a betting shop on the [[Commodore PET]].<ref name=crash14>{{cite magazine
column3: title=I BET TOLKIEN DID THE SAME
column7: issue=14}}</ref>  Moving on from this, he began working on [[arcade game]]s for the Pet, working with PetSoft, where he wrote ''Space Ace'' entirely in [[MOS Technology 6502
column8: 6502]] [[machine code]].  The game broke sales records of the day by selling three hundred copies.<ref name=crash41>{{cite magazine

column1: Singleton's association with PetSoft turned out to be short-lived, as PetSoft, who had been due to enter into a contract with [[Sinclair Research Ltd.
column2: Sinclair Research]] in [[Cambridge]] to write software for the new [[Sinclair ZX80
column3: ZX80]], lost out on the deal to [[Psion (computers)
column4: Psion]].  Singleton contacted British inventor and entrepreneur [[Clive Sinclair]] and was asked to send his games along.<ref name=crash41 />  He was then asked to visit the site in Cambridge, and invited to work on software for their brand new [[Sinclair ZX81

column1: Singleton used this as the platform for his ''GamesPack1'' project. ''GamesPack1'' was a series of games, each fitting into just 1 [[kilobyte]] of memory.  It was one of the first commercial software programs written for the ZX81, and something of a runaway success, selling a massive 90,000 copies, earning Singleton [[Pound sterling
column2: £]]6,000 for his efforts,<ref name=crash41 /> having taken him just two weeks over the Christmas holidays to complete.<ref name=crash14 />

column1: Whilst the arcade game writing business was making him a living, Singleton, who retired from teaching completely in 1982 to become a full-time freelance [[video game designer
column2: games designer]], was always an old school war gamer at heart,<ref name=sua85>{{cite magazine
column8: pages=39–42}}</ref> hooked from an early age on war [[board game]]s and [[Play-by-mail game
column9: play-by-mail]] (PBM) strategy gaming, working for a time on ''Seventh Empire'', a PBM game he put together for ''[[Computer and Video Games (magazine)
column10: Computer and Video Games]]'' magazine (''C&VG''),<ref name=sua85 /> which eventually led to [[Beyond Software]] when ''C&VG'' editor Terry Pratt moved to run Beyond.<ref name=crash14 />

column1: In March 1984, Singleton's spy-themed board game, ''Treachery'', which had its complicated game logic controlled by a computer program, was featured in ''C&VG'', with a type-in listing for the Spectrum, together with a keyboard overlay (a common feature of his games), centre-spread board and a set of counters.  The game was so popular among the readers that the editor asked for conversions for the [[Commodore 64]] and [[BBC Micro]] to be produced, and each of them featured in ''C&VG'''s 1985 yearbook.

It was from Beyond that Singleton, who remained freelance, was by September 1983 being pressed for more programs, and having progressed to the Sinclair ZX Spectrum, he wrote what are widely regarded as some of the best strategy adventure games ever to be seen on those early home microcomputers,<ref name=\"PlanSinc\">{{cite web
column3: title=Planet Sinclair: The Sinclair Industry: Programmers: Mike Singleton
column6: accessdate=2016-06-27}}</ref> the ''Midnight'' series: ''[[Lords of Midnight]]'' (released in July 1984) and ''[[Doomdark's Revenge]]'', which were originally intended to form the first two episodes in a trilogy of which, the final episode, ''[[Eye of the Moon]]'', never came about. Each of the two games played out on a scale never seen before back in the mid-eighties, at a time when many games were boasting 50 or even 100 locations, ''Lords of Midnight'''s groundbreaking gameplay featured over 4,000 locations, and ''Doomdark's Revenge'', 6,000, plus well in excess of 100 player controllable characters.  Had ''Eye of the Moon'' come to fruition, it was to have had around 24,000 locations, in a map featuring twelve distinct regions, each with a local sub-quest completely separate from the main objective of the game.<ref name=crash41 />

column1: Moving on from the ''Midnight'' series, Singleton worked on several games of a more arcade-like nature, the first of which, ''[[Throne of Fire]]'',<ref name=\"PlanSinc\" /> a side viewed live action game, featured a multiplayer option where each player used the same computer to explore simultaneously, each trying to complete a set of objectives which lead to the overall completion of the game. ''[[Dark Sceptre]]'',<ref name=\"PlanSinc\" /> released later the same year, was also in essence a sideways viewed live action game, but returned to a more adventure-like feel, with a long, drawn out challenge awaiting the player who would need to build up their forces to consolidate their position before seizing on the opportunity to actually complete the game.

Two years later, ''[[War in Middle-earth]]'',<ref name=\"PlanSinc\" /> whilst essentially an [[adventure game]] on a similar scale to the ''Midnight'' series, represented a switch from the adventure to an action philosophy, requiring the player to interact with the characters under their control directly, moving them individually in each of the battles,<ref name=crash41 /> giving the game much more of an arcade/adventure feel.
In the late 1980s, Singleton moved onto the [[16-bit]] machines that were making an appearance, and worked on the classic ''[[Midwinter (video game)
column2: Midwinter]]'' trilogy, also producing another work in the ''Lords of Midnight'' series in 1995, [[Lords of Midnight: The Citadel]].

column1: In the 21st century, Singleton continued working in games design, making him one of a few developers to have made the transition to more modern consoles from the early days of home computing. Singleton worked for [[Midas Interactive]] and [[LucasArts]] on several games for the [[Xbox (console)
column2: Xbox]] and [[PlayStation]] consoles, such as the action games ''[[HyperSonic Xtreme]]'' and ''[[Indiana Jones and the Emperor's Tomb]]''. Singleton worked on the strategy game ''[[Wrath Unleashed]]'', with his latest productions being ''[[Gauntlet: Seven Sorrows]]'', a continuation of the 80s arcade classic ''[[Gauntlet (arcade game)
column3: Gauntlet]]'' series of games, and ''[[Race Driver: Grid]]'', a racing game developed by [[Codemasters]].<ref>{{moby developer
column5: name=Singleton's profile}}</ref> At the time of his death after suffering from cancer,<ref>{{Citation
column6: title = RIP Mike Singleton, the RPG visionary who revolutionised the genre
column12: accessdate = 30 November 2019}}</ref> Singleton was working on an iPhone port of ''Lords of Midnight''.<ref>{{cite web

column1: * [http://www.midnightmu.com Midnight/MU – A browser-based multiplayer game based on The Lords of Midnight/Doomdarks Revenge]

column2: Communications field focused on bringing climate change information to a public}}

column1: '''Climate communication''' or '''climate change communication''' is a field of [[environmental communication]]s and [[science communication]] focused on facilitating the communications of the effects of [[Global warming
column2: anthropogenic climate change]]. Most climate communication focuses on bringing knowledge from the scientific consensus on the impact of climate change to a broader public.

column1: The field of climate communication explores two main areas: the efficacy of existing communications strategies, and supporting the development of recommendations for improving that communication. Improving climate change communication has become the focus of several major research institutes, such as the [[Yale Program on Climate Change Communication]] and Climate Outreach in the UK, as well as major international organizations, such as the IPCC and [[UN Climate Change Secretariat]], and [[Non-governmental organization

In her encyclopedia article in Oxford's Communications Research Encyclopedia, scholar Amy E. Chadwick describes Climate Change Communication as a new field emerging in the 1990s.<ref name=\":2\">{{Cite web
column14: access-date=2020-04-13}}</ref> Early studies were connected to other environmental communications concerns such as exploring awareness and understanding of [[ozone depletion]].<ref name=\":2\" /> {{As of
column16: }}, most research in this field has been conducted in the United States, Australia, Canada, and Western European countries.<ref name=\":2\" />

column1: Because of the importance of the larger scale [[Climate change mitigation
column2: public action required in addressing climate change]], a significant part of climate communications is focused on understanding barriers to public understanding and action on climate change. In particular, the evidence shows that the [[information deficit model]] of communication—where climate change communicators assume  \"if the public only knew more about the evidence they would act\"—doesn't work. Instead, [[argumentation theory]] indicates that different audiences need different kinds of persuasive argumentation and communication.
climate denialism]] by organizations such as the [[The Heartland Institute]] in the United States, introduces [[misinformation]] into public discourse and understanding.

column1: There are several models for explaining why the public doesn't act once more informed. One of the theoretical models for this is the 5 Ds model created by [[Per Espen Stoknes
column4: title=The 5 psychological barriers to climate action
column10: access-date=2020-04-12}}</ref> Stokes describes 5 major barriers to creating action from climate communication:

column1: # '''Distance''' - many effects and impacts of climate change feel distant from individual lives
# '''Doom -''' when framed as a disaster, the message backfires, causing [[Eco-anxiety]]
# '''Dissonance''' - a disconnect between the problems (mainly the fossil fuel economy) and the things that people choose in their lives
# '''Denial''' -- psychological self defense to avoid becoming overwhelmed by fear or guilt
# '''iDentity''' -- disconnects created by social identities, such as [[Conservatism
column2: conservative]] values, which are threatened by the changes that need to happen because of climate change.

column1: As of 2008, most of the environmental communications evidence for effecting individual or social change were focused on behavior changes around: [[Domestic energy consumption
column3: recycling behaviours]], changing transportation behavior and buying green products.<ref name=\":1\" /> At that time, there were few examples of [[multi-level communications]] strategies for effecting change.<ref name=\":1\" />

column1: Different parts of different populations respond differently to climate change communication. Academic research since 2013 has seen an increasing number of [[audience segmentation]] studies, to understand different tactics for reaching different parts of populations.<ref>{{Cite journal
column15: title=Audience segmentation and climate change communication: conceptual and methodological considerations: Audience segmentation and climate change communication

column2: US}} Segmentation of the American audiences into 6 groups:<ref>{{Cite journal
column16: title=Global Warming's \"Six Americas Short Survey\": Audience Segmentation of Climate Change Views Using a Four Question Instrument
column23: issn=1752-4032}}</ref> Alarmed, Concerned,Cautious, Disengaged, Doubtful and Dismissive.

column2: AUS}} Segmentation of Australians into 4 segments in 2011,<ref>{{Cite web
column12: title=Communication and climate change: What the Australian public thinks
column15: doi=10.4225/08/584ee953cdee1}}</ref> and 6 segments analogous to the Six America's model.<ref>{{Cite journal
column25: title=A comparison between attitudes to climate change in Australia and the United States

column2: DE}} Segmentation of German populations into 5 segments<ref>{{Cite journal
column10: title=Global warming's five Germanys: A typology of Germans' views on climate change and patterns of media use and information

column2: India}} Segmentation of Indian populations into the 6 segments<ref>{{Cite web
column5: website=Yale Program on Climate Change Communication

column2: Singapore}} Segmentation of Singapore audiences into 3 segments<ref>{{Cite journal
column10: title=Digitoxin metabolism by rat liver microsomes

column1: A significant part of the research and public advocacy conversations about climate change have focused on the effectiveness of different terms used to describe \"global warming\".

column2: Climate change and health}}Climate change exacerbates a number of existing public health issues, such as [[mosquito-borne disease]], and introduces new public health concerns related to changing climate, such as increase in health concerns after natural disasters or increases in [[heat illness]]es. Thus the field of [[health communication]] has long acknowledged the importance of treating climate change as a public health issue, requiring broad population behavior changes that allow societal [[climate change adaptation]].<ref name=\":1\">{{Cite journal
column10: title=Communication and Marketing As Climate Change–Intervention Assets
column17: pmid=18929975}}</ref> A December 2008 article in the [[American Journal of Preventive Medicine]] recommended using two broad sets of tools to effect this change: communication and [[social marketing]].<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: The effect of mass media and journalism on the public's attitudes towards climate change has been a significant part of communications studies. In particular, scholars have looked at how the media's tendency to cover climate change in different cultural contexts, with different audiences or political positions (for example [[Fox News]]'s dismissive coverage of climate change news), and the tendency of newsrooms to cover climate change as a issue of uncertainty or debate, in order to give a sense of balance.<ref name=\":2\" />

Further research has explored how popular media, like the film ''[[The Day After Tomorrow]]'' and popular documentary [[An Inconvenient Truth]] change public perceptions of climate change.<ref name=\":2\" />

Effective climate communications require audience and contextual awareness. Different organizations have published guides and frameworks based on experience in climate communications. This section documents those various guidelines.

column2: IPCC]] published a handbook of guidance for IPCC authors about effective climate communication. It is based on extensive social studies research exploring the impact of different tactics for climate communication.<ref>{{Cite web
column13: access-date=2020-04-12}}</ref> The guidelines focus on six main principles:

column1: # Talk about the real world, not abstract ideas
# Connect with what matters to your audience
# Use the most effective visual communication
Climate Visuals a nonprofit, publishes a set of guidelines based on evidence for climate communications.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=2020-04-12}}</ref> They recommend that visual communications include:

column1: # Show climate change causes at scale

The impacts of climate change are exacerbated in low- and middle income countries; higher levels of poverty, less access to technologies, and less education, means that this audience needs different information. The [[Paris Agreement]] and [[IPCC]] both acknowledge the importance of [[sustainable development]] in addressing these differences. Non profit, [[Climate and Development Knowledge Network]] published a set of [[lessons learned]] and guidelines based on their experience communicating climate change in Latin America, Asia and Africa.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=GUIDE: Communicating climate change - A practitioner's guide

column1: Major research centers in climate communication include:
* [[Center for Climate Change Communication]] at [[George Mason University]]
